title: Musical Instruments & Music History
description: From classical symphony to jazz and rock â€” test your knowledge of musical instruments and music history!

questions.question: Around what year was the piano invented?
questions.explanation: The piano was invented around 1700 by Bartolomeo Cristofori in Italy. He called it the 'pianoforte' because unlike the harpsichord, it could play both soft (piano) and loud (forte) notes.

questions.question: Which of these instruments is NOT part of the violin family?
questions.explanation: The oboe is a woodwind instrument, not a string instrument. The violin family consists of the violin, viola, cello, and double bass, all played with a bow.

questions.question: How many strings does a standard acoustic guitar have?
questions.explanation: A standard guitar has 6 strings. The strings are typically tuned to E, A, D, G, B, and E from lowest to highest. Bass guitars, by contrast, usually have 4 strings.

questions.question: Who invented the saxophone?
questions.explanation: Belgian instrument maker Adolphe Sax invented the saxophone in the early 1840s and patented it in 1846. He designed it to bridge the gap between brass and woodwind instruments.

questions.question: The trumpet is a key instrument in which genre of American music?
questions.explanation: The trumpet is central to jazz music, with legends like Louis Armstrong and Miles Davis defining the genre. Armstrong's innovative style in the 1920s helped make jazz a worldwide phenomenon.

questions.question: What is the large drum that produces a deep, booming sound in an orchestra called?
questions.explanation: Timpani, also called kettledrums, are large copper drums that can be tuned to specific pitches. A standard orchestra typically uses four timpani, and they've been used in orchestras since the 17th century.

questions.question: A pipe organ produces sound by sending air through what?
questions.explanation: Pipe organs produce sound by pushing air through pipes that vary in size from a few inches to over 30 feet long. The largest pipe organ in the world, at Boardwalk Hall in Atlantic City, has over 33,000 pipes.

questions.question: Antonio Stradivari was a famous maker of which instrument?
questions.explanation: Stradivari crafted violins, violas, and cellos in Cremona, Italy, during the late 1600s and early 1700s. His instruments are considered the finest ever made, with some selling for over $15 million.

questions.question: The harmonica is also known by what other name?
questions.explanation: The harmonica is commonly called a mouth organ because the player blows and draws air through it. It became hugely popular in blues music, with players like Little Walter and Sonny Boy Williamson.

questions.question: The banjo is believed to have originated from instruments brought to America from which continent?
questions.explanation: The banjo evolved from African stringed instruments brought to America by enslaved people. It became central to American folk, bluegrass, and country music by the 19th century.

questions.question: A classical symphony orchestra is traditionally divided into how many main sections?
questions.explanation: An orchestra has four main sections: strings, woodwinds, brass, and percussion. The strings section is the largest, making up more than half of a typical orchestra.

questions.question: Ludwig van Beethoven continued composing music even after losing which sense?
questions.explanation: Beethoven began losing his hearing in his late 20s and was almost completely deaf by 1814. He composed some of his greatest works, including his Ninth Symphony, while profoundly deaf.

questions.question: At what age did Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart begin composing music?
questions.explanation: Mozart began composing at age 5 and wrote his first symphony at age 8. Despite dying at just 35, he composed over 600 works, including 41 symphonies and 27 piano concertos.

questions.question: In standard music notation, how many lines make up a musical staff?
questions.explanation: A standard musical staff has 5 lines and 4 spaces, each representing a different musical pitch. The modern five-line staff became standard in the 16th century.

questions.question: Tchaikovsky composed which famous ballet that is traditionally performed during the Christmas season?
questions.explanation: 'The Nutcracker' premiered in 1892 in St. Petersburg, Russia. Its 'Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy' features the celesta, a keyboard instrument Tchaikovsky specifically chose for its magical, bell-like sound.
